title: New Hampshire Democratic Debate: The Moments That Mattered; Days before the first-in-nation primary, Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders drew the most attention after their strong finish in Iowa
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Seven Democratic presidential candidates
took the stage
in New Hampshire on Friday night, days ahead of the state's the first-in-the-nation primary next week.
The top finishers in the
Iowa caucuses
this week, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg drew the most attention from their rivals. Former Vice President Joe Biden and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, whose Iowa results fell short of what they'd hoped, tried to make their case to voters across the country. Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar, billionaire climate activist Tom Steyer and entrepreneur Andrew Yang also shared the debate stage. The candidates squared off over experience and who was best suited to take on President Donald Trump in the general election.
Pete Buttigieg was in opponents' crosshairs.
"We have a newcomer in the White House, and look where it got us."—Amy Klobuchar
Why this matters: Ms. Klobuchar was citing President Trump's political novelty as she hit Pete Buttigieg over his inexperience compared with the other top Democratic contenders. Ms. Klobuchar and Joe Biden trained their ire on Mr. Buttigieg, the 38-year-old former mayor of South Bend, Ind., who appears to have tied with Mr. Sanders to win the Iowa caucuses this week. The trio of more moderate candidates are vying for independents in New Hampshire and center-left Democrats across the country.
As she warned that the country shouldn't take another risk on a political newcomer, Ms. Klobuchar also chided Mr. Buttigieg, "Mayor Pete, while three of us were jurors in the impeachment hearing, you said you wanted to turn the channel and watch cartoons. It's easy to go after Washington. It's much harder to lead."
Mr. Buttigieg responded to those kinds of attacks by contrasting himself to the third-term Minnesota senator and Mr. Biden, a senator and vice president for 4½ decades. "We cannot solve the problems before us by looking back," Mr. Buttigieg said.
Bernie Sanders pressed on identifying as a "democratic socialist."
"Bernie said he wrote the damn bill, but didn't say how he'll pay for the damn thing."—Joe Biden
Why this matters: Mr. Biden hammered Mr. Sanders over his refusal to talk about how he would fund his Medicare for All plan. The candidates opened the three-hour debate with a discussion of their health care plans—and immediately showed more willingness to confront each other than in past debates. Early on, a moderator asked the candidates to raise their hands if they thought having a democratic socialist at the top of the ticket was a problem. Ms. Klobuchar appeared to be the only candidate on the stage to do so.
Earlier, Mr. Biden had said that Mr. Trump would apply the label socialist to "everyone running with Bernie if he's the nominee." Mr. Sanders responded to such criticism by saying Mr. Trump lies about everything, so it doesn't matter what people worry he might say. He also argued he could bring broad swaths of Americans together by rallying them around more affordable health care and decrying income inequality.
Michael Bloomberg looms large despite not being on stage.
"I don't think anyone ought to be able to buy their way into the nomination or being president of the United States."—Elizabeth Warren
Why this matters: The debate moderators asked the candidates on stage what they thought about billionaire former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg's self-financed effort to win the Democratic nomination despite sitting out the first four primary contests. Mr. Bloomberg hasn't qualified for any of the debates so far, but the Democratic National Committee recently changed its criteria in such a way that he could be on future stages.
Ms. Klobuchar cited her working-class upbringing and spouted another Trump-themed zinger. "I don't think people look at the guy in the White House and think, 'Can we get someone richer?'"
A moderator baited Mr. Sanders on the topic by saying the former mayor had said "we need evolution, not revolution," a riff on Mr. Sanders's campaign theme. Mr. Sanders called it "nonsense" that Mr. Bloomberg can spend hundreds of millions of dollars on his own campaign, and plugged his 1.5 million donors who had given an average of just over $18 each.
Candidates wrestle with abortion and the Supreme Court.
"I will never nominate any person to the Supreme Court or the federal courts in general who is not 100% pro Roe V. Wade."—Bernie Sanders
Why This Matters: Other candidates on stage gave sometimes meandering answers to a question about whether they would only nominate Supreme Court judges who would keep abortion legal. "I would only appoint judges that would respect precedent. And one of those key precedents is Roe v. Wade," Ms. Klobuchar said. Mr. Biden gave a lengthy answer about the kinds of justices he had backed in the past.
Mr. Sanders said that he would only nominate justices fully supportive of upholding Roe v. Wade, referring to the 1973 court decision that legalized abortion. Billionaire Tom Steyer said he, too, has a litmus test and argued that all of the candidates were in agreement. "Everybody on this row feels exactly the same way about a woman's right to choose," he said.
Candidates forced to disavow their own surrogates
"I believe he's sorry for what he said."—Joe Biden
Why this matters: Mr. Steyer confronted Mr. Biden over a remark that his longtime friend and campaign surrogate in South Carolina Dick Harpootlian made. Mr. Harpootlian, a Democratic state senator, said the head of the state's black legislative caucus only backed Mr. Steyer because he was paid to do so, something other black lawmakers decried as a racist remark. Mr. Harpootlian denies that his comment was racially motivated, according to the Associated Press, and on the debate stage, Mr. Biden said he'd spoken to Mr. Harpootlian and believed he was sorry.
Soon after, a debate moderator asked Mr. Sanders about an opinion piece his campaign co-chair Nina Turner wrote asserting that Mr. Biden has "repeatedly betrayed black voters." Mr. Sanders said he did not agree with Ms. Turner's assessment. "Joe Biden is a friend of mine, and I'm not here to attack him," he said.
Write to Julie Bykowicz at
julie.bykowicz@wsj.com

title: Health-Care, Tech Shares Underperform in Election Years
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
If history is any guide, the 2020 election year may not bode well for stocks in the health-care or technology sectors.
But the S&P 500 as a whole may do just fine.
The health-care and technology segments of the S&P 500 typically suffer their worst performance of the four-year election cycle during the years Americans go to the polls to name a president.
That is according to an analysis of sector performance by Dow Jones Market Data going back to 1928, the year in which Republican Herbert Hoover won the presidency by defeating Democrat Al Smith.
The broader market, on the other hand, has averaged its best performance in the year before elections, followed by the year in which voters pick a new occupant for the White House.
This year, the outlook for stocks is bolstered by an economy that is marching along as well as by recent progress on trade agreements, said Jamie Cox, managing partner for Harris Financial Group.
"That should clear the decks for markets to do quite well throughout this year," he said.
Last year's standout S&P 500 advance of 29% -- its best showing since 2013 -- fit the historical trend and beat the average gain of 13.5% in pre-election years. Investment-bank strategists expect more modest results in 2020. Goldman Sachs Group Inc., for one, predicts the index will end the year at 3400, which would mark a 5.2% rise. Its average gain in election years is 9.1%.
As far as the historical election-year laggards: The health-care sector has received particular attention from investors during the current presidential campaign, with some Democratic candidates proposing major changes to how Americans get health insurance.
Bernie Sanders has proposed a Medicare-for-All plan that would move every American to a government-run health-insurance plan, even if they have insurance through their employer. Elizabeth Warren has endorsed a similar approach.
Although health-care stocks often are considered defensive investments -- demand for health care doesn't generally fluctuate with the economy -- they can be vulnerable to changes in government policy.
Health-care stocks were the next-to-worst performing sector in the S&P 500 in 2019, after energy. Some analysts pegged their trajectory to the progressive Democrats' rise and fall in the polls. So far in 2020, the shares are slightly underperforming the broader market, rising 2.5% versus a gain of 2.8% by the S&P 500. Their average gain in election years is 7.9%
Technology stocks, on the other hand, had a standout year in 2019, surging 48%. They continue to lead the S&P 500 in 2020, with a gain of 5.8% -- slightly ahead of the average increase of 5% in election years.
Shares of technology companies have powered the decadelong bull market, with investors putting their money behind rapidly growing enterprises that many expect will outperform the broader economy. That is even as big tech companies face antitrust probes and controversies over their handling of user data.
Those concerns, combined with the relative priciness of technology stocks, could pose risks for the sector in 2020, Mr. Cox said.
"It could be this year tech is beaten up by candidates more than health care," he said.
In contrast, three sectors have had their best average performance in presidential-election years: financials, utilities and energy. Those are generally considered slower-growing companies. Financial and energy shares are often categorized as value stocks, or those with a low price-to-book value, while utilities are deemed safety stocks because of their high dividend yields.
DJMD's sector analysis excludes returns from 2008, when the S&P 500 suffered an outsize decline of 38% in the depths of the financial crisis. When including performance from that year, seven of the 11 sectors in the index average their weakest performance during presidential-election years.

title: Sanders Campaign Looks to Move On From Caucus Chaos; Vermont senator declared victory in Iowa while results were still coming in, announced big January fundraising
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





Volunteers and supporters of Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders at a watch party during the Iowa caucuses on Monday. Mr. Sanders's presidential campaign is now pivoting to New Hampshire. PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
When the going gets tough, Bernie Sanders's aides talk about what happened on Oct. 4.
That was the day the Vermont senator left the hospital after a heart attack, just after the lowest point in his presidential bid, and a reminder that the campaign has proven it can turn things around.
This week, after chaotic results out of the Iowa Democratic Party and no clear answer about who won the state's presidential caucuses, aides acknowledged frustration. So the campaign sought to reset ahead of next week's New Hampshire primary, declaring victory in Iowa while results were still coming in and disclosing massive January fundraising.
Mr. Sanders had a lead in the popular vote with 97% of precincts reporting as of Thursday. But he and former South Bend Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg were locked in a tight race for the metric that Iowa Democrats consider most important, so-called state delegate equivalents.
On Thursday, the Associated Press said it would be unable to declare a winner in the contest, citing the close margin between Messrs. Buttigieg and Sanders as well as "irregularities in this year's caucus process."
And the chairman of the Democratic Party called for a recanvass—the auditing of paper records from each precinct's caucus—after technical problems marred the tabulation of results.
"Where I come from and where everybody else comes from, the person who gets the most votes wins," Mr. Sanders said during a press conference in Manchester, N.H. "We got the most votes."
In interviews, Mr. Sanders's top aides said they plan to stick with their strategy of appealing to young people and minorities, saying the candidate did well in Iowa precincts with large populations of those groups. On Thursday,
the campaign announced it received $25 million from grass-roots donors in January
—more than many candidates raised in entire quarters last year—and said it is investing $5.5 million in advertising in 10 states set to vote in late February and early March.
Mr. Sanders has been leading in polls in New Hampshire, too.
"I am confident that here in New Hampshire, I know you'll be able to count your votes on election night," Mr. Sanders told a crowd in Milford, N.H., Tuesday night. "And when you count those votes, I look forward to winning here in New Hampshire."
The Iowa results carried some warning signs for Mr. Sanders.
The close race with Mr. Buttigieg
, a 38-year-old Washington outsider who has sought to appeal to moderates, reveals the Democratic Party remains ideologically divided and is still deciding what type of candidate should take on President Trump.
Some more centrist voters worry that Mr. Sanders—a self-described Democratic socialist—could scare off moderate Republicans and independent voters looking for an alternative to Mr. Trump. And Mr. Sanders could face difficulty expanding his base if the field narrows. His strategy to rack up delegates relies on a fractured Democrats field. If candidates were to drop out, early voters could coalesce around one of his opponents.
Share Your Thoughts
Are you awaiting the official results of Iowa's Democratic caucuses to help decide between candidates? Why or why not? Join the conversation below.
The caucuses also saw lower-than-expected turnout, despite the Vermont senator's vow to expand the electorate.
Mr. Sanders narrowly lost the state in his long-shot bid for the Democratic nomination in 2016. This time, Mr. Sanders announced his run in February with strong name identification and a more experienced team.
To move ahead of a crowded field, the Sanders campaign invested in its ground game in Iowa. On Feb. 1, the campaign announced it had knocked on half a million doors since the beginning of January. As of Monday, the Sanders campaign had bought nearly $11 million worth of TV and radio advertisements in the state, trailing just businessman Tom Steyer, who spent over $16 million.
Jane O'Meara Sanders, Mr. Sanders's wife, also said campaigning in the final days before the caucuses felt different than it did four years ago.
"I felt that in 2016, we were introducing him at every venue, we were introducing Bernie Sanders to Iowa," Mrs. Sanders said in an interview the weekend before the Iowa caucuses. 





Mr. Sanders's supporters in Iowa PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
While nine out of 10 people in Iowa are white, the Sanders campaign also
focused on increasing turnout from voters in minority communities
and sent organizers to talk with people in areas with large Latino populations, said Misty Rebik, his Iowa state director. Mr. Sanders also held an event on a Native American settlement in Iowa and focused on how his policies would affect those in attendance. Mr. Sanders and the rest of the field have struggled for the support of African-American voters, particularly older ones, who have flocked to former Vice President Joe Biden.
Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez met with Latinos on her trips to the state. Her decision to endorse the Vermont senator while he was still in the hospital last fall helped give a shot of energy to a lagging campaign, as did those of two other liberal congresswomen, Rep. Ilhan Omar (D., Minn.) and Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D., Mich.).
All three were in Iowa for Mr. Sanders in the last two weeks, campaigning across the state as he was stuck in Washington for the impeachment trial of Mr. Trump.
Aides believe Mr. Sanders was able to consolidate support in the final weeks after voters looked at other candidates and compared them to Mr. Sanders, who has been calling for the same policies for decades.
Heather Purdy, a 45-year-old professor from Des Moines, said she had decided on Mr. Sanders the week before the caucuses. Ms. Purdy had been considering Mr. Sanders and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, but she said the Vermont lawmaker's consistency ultimately won her over. "He's had the same platform for the last 40 years," she said.
Chad Day and Joshua Jamerson contributed to this article.
Write to Eliza Collins at
eliza.collins@wsj.com.

title: Iowa's Tally-by-App Experiment Fails; Faulty kickoff leads Democratic candidates to express frustration
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





Caucus officials on the Drake University campus counting how many seats are represented for each candidate, in Des Moines, Iowa, on Monday evening. PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
Glitches to a mobile app and a backup phone-in plan for reporting results in Iowa's Democratic presidential caucuses delayed the outcome and heightened concerns about the integrity of the voting process in the 2020 elections.
After Monday night's failure, some Democratic Party officials in the 1,700-plus caucus sites complained about the rollout and difficulties in downloading and using the app. Some said a final version was only made available this past weekend. Still, others said that when they tried to phone results to party leaders, they were put on hold or disconnected.
The faulty kickoff led Democratic candidates to express frustration. Nevada's State Democratic Party, which holds its caucuses later this month, announced that it wouldn't use the app that malfunctioned in Iowa.
Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez said the app "did not function adequately" and won't be used again in any future primary election contest.
The Iowa Democratic Party had been warned by security experts that the app hadn't been stress tested or vetted for statewide use. Bob Lord, the DNC's cybersecurity chief, also urged Iowa to drop plans to use the app, an overture that was ignored, according to people familiar with the matter. Mr. Lord declined to comment.
The Iowa Democratic Party chairman, Troy Price, said that no cyber intrusion occurred and that paper records ensure the data on results are accurate. While the data was collected accurately by the app, he said, an underlying coding error that affected how figures were reported was discovered and corrected.
"We took the steps we felt was necessary, but we found a coding error last night once we discovered some irregularities," Mr. Price said during an afternoon press conference held almost a full day after the caucuses began, shortly before partial results were released. Apologizing for the problems, Mr. Price promised a full, transparent investigation. "What happened last night was simply unacceptable."
The debacle in Iowa's first-in-the-nation nominating contest threatened to shake voter confidence in the electoral process at the start of the 2020 voting season, election and cybersecurity experts said.
"The big risk is that disruptions and uncertainty like this will be exploited to discourage people from voting," said Matt Blaze, an election security expert and professor of computer science at Georgetown University.
The app at the center of the controversy was built by a small Washington, D.C.-based company, Shadow Inc., the tech arm of a nonprofit progressive digital strategy firm Acronym. State records show that the Iowa Democratic Party paid Shadow a little more than $63,000 over two payments in November and December.
Shadow, in a series of tweets, apologized on Tuesday for the app's performance and said that the company "worked as quickly as possible overnight to resolve this issue."
Cybersecurity experts and U.S. election security officials said that while no hacking or other foul play had been detected, the app hadn't been security tested or vetted for statewide use—something Mr. Price disputed.
"Our Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency had offered to test the app," Chad Wolf, the acting secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, said Tuesday on "Fox & Friends," the Fox network's flagship morning program. "They declined." Mr. Price said he wasn't aware of any offer.
More from Iowa
*
Candidates Pivot to New Hampshire With Iowa in Flux

*
Iowa Result? More Uncertainty

*
Democratic Caucus Results in Iowa Delayed by Counting Problems

*
Iowa Caucuses—Live Analysis

Some Democratic campaigns, including those of former Vice President Joe Biden and Pete Buttigieg, have used a Shadow-built app to send text messages to supporters and solicit donations, according to federal campaign expense records and people familiar with the matter. The Biden campaign halted its use of that app amid concerns about its reliability.
"Our campaign used Shadow only once and on a very small scale, for sending text messages to voters about our campaign kickoff in Philadelphia," a Biden aide told The Wall Street Journal. "Our IT team expressed security concerns about it, and it ultimately did not pass our cybersecurity checklist, so we declined to use it again."
Election security became a priority for state officials, the political parties and the campaigns after the hacking of Hillary Clinton's campaign chairman's email and divisive social media postings by what U.S. intelligence agencies say were Russian groups roiled the 2016 election. 





Volunteers and supporters on the Drake University campus to caucus for their preferred candidate in Des Moines on Monday. PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
In a partisan political atmosphere when elections are sometimes decided by thin margins, delays in reporting results may stoke doubt. Overhauls in many states still allow a lengthy period to complete and certify results; California, which moved its primary to early March from June, has 30 days from election day
to final certification
.
In Iowa, the confusion over the app fueled intraparty squabbling among Democrats. Supporters for Bernie Sanders, who had been leading in several polls, took to social media to revisit grievances from the 2016 election when hacked Democratic National Committee emails showed some bias by party officials in favor of Mrs. Clinton over Mr. Sanders.
Trump campaign officials also seemed to touch on Democratic divisions, questioning whether the app problems and the Iowa party's checking of the data were designed to favor a particular candidate. "Quality control = rigged?" tweeted Brad Parscale, manager for President Trump's re-election campaign.
Acronym distanced itself from Shadow, saying in statements that it is one of a number of investors in the company and that the two "are distinct organizations, with separate teams of employees." Acronym said it wasn't involved in the development of the app or in Shadow's work with the Iowa Democratic Party.
Last year, Acronym Chief Executive Tara McGowan said it was launching Shadow as part of an acquisition of a political customer-relationship management tool.
Acronym is led by Ms. McGowan, a Democratic political strategist, and has several related arms, including a political-action committee with a roughly $75 million advertising budget to target voters in swing states. She is married to a senior aide in Mr. Buttigieg's campaign, a connection that earned widespread attention on social media.
Mr. Buttigieg's campaign "didn't have anything to do with the design of the app," a Buttigieg aide said, while adding the campaign's contract with the firm predates that of the Iowa Democratic Party.
Until Monday night, party officials declined to identify the app's developer. The office of Sen. Ron Wyden (D., Ore.) asked the Democratic National Committee three times about details regarding the app during the lead-up to the Iowa caucuses, but received no reply, an aide to the senator said.
Problems with the Shadow app surfaced Monday in Iowa before voting started, with some precinct leaders saying they had trouble downloading or logging onto the app. The Iowa Democratic Party said the reported issues were mainly from areas with poor cell service or involved minor user errors that were being resolved.
Some precinct officials in rural areas didn't know about the app until a few weeks ago, received no training and decided not to use it, said Tracy Freese, chair of the Democratic Party in Grundy County, who also serves as a precinct chair. She opted to call in results, as she did for previous caucuses.
Ms. Freese said she tried to get her results through on the hotline, but was put on hold and gave up after 12:30 a.m. She called back early this morning and didn't get someone on the phone until 6 a.m. Mr. Price, the Iowa Democratic Party chief, answered.
"I don't know what the hell is going on," she said.
The state party said last month that it would record votes from the Iowa caucuses using the smartphone app because that would be easier and faster to report results.
The app was intended to help the precinct chairs record the results from each round of voting and take care of the calculations to apportion delegates. Then the precinct chair was supposed to use the app to send the results to the Iowa Democratic Party.
But the final version wasn't ready until this past weekend, according to precinct chairs.
Joel Miller, county auditor and commissioner of elections in Cedar Rapids who volunteered to host his precinct's caucus, said he downloaded the final version of the app onto his iPhone on Saturday. When he did, he received a download link that took him to TestFlight, which is used to test new apps not ready to be shared via the Apple Store. Through TestFlight, Mr. Miller said he was able to access the vote reporting app.
Capital Journal in Your Inbox
Get the latest scoops, analysis and insights driving Washington from the WSJ's D.C. bureau, with Capital Journal.
Sign up.

Emily Glazer, Deepa Seetharaman and Sabrina Siddiqui contributed to this article.
Write to Dustin Volz at
dustin.volz@wsj.com
, Tarini Parti at
Tarini.Parti@wsj.com
, Alexa Corse at
alexa.corse@wsj.com
and Robert McMillan at
Robert.Mcmillan@wsj.com

title: Bernie Sanders Wins New Hampshire Primary; Vermont senator narrowly beats Pete Buttigieg, with Amy Klobuchar coming in third
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





Bernie Sanders addresses supporters at his primary-night celebration held at Southern New Hampshire University. PHOTO: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal
CONCORD, N.H.—Sen. Bernie Sanders won the New Hampshire Democratic presidential primary Tuesday night in a narrow victory that ensures the race to challenge President Trump this November will remain heated.
With more than 85% of precincts reporting, Mr. Sanders, who is from neighboring Vermont, had 25.7% of the vote, followed by Pete Buttigieg with 24.4% and Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota with 19.7%.
Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and former Vice President Joe Biden, who each have previously led the Democratic field in national polling, lagged well behind with less than 10% of the vote.
"Let me say tonight that this victory here is the beginning of the end for Donald Trump," Mr. Sanders said to loud cheers at a watch party in Manchester. He also struck a tone of unity as he thanked his fellow candidates, who he said he respected.
"No matter who wins, and we certainly hope it's going to be us, we're going to unite together. We are going to unite together and defeat the most dangerous president in the modern history of this country," Mr. Sanders said.
The 78-year-old self-described democratic socialist
had expected a strong showing here
would propel him into contests in Nevada and South Carolina, two states where he lost to Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential primary. That year, Mr. Sanders easily won in New Hampshire with more than 60% of the vote.
Mr. Sanders's win, following his near-tie with Mr. Buttigieg in last week's Iowa caucuses, showcased the resilience of a candidate who only months ago suffered a
heart attack while campaigning in Nevada
. The Associated Press called the New Hampshire primary for Mr. Sanders shortly after 11:40 p.m. EST. 





The win propels Mr. Sanders into contests in Nevada and South Carolina, two states where he lost to Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential primary. PHOTO: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal
The victory came as candidates seeking to challenge Mr. Trump began shifting focus to two more diverse states and to later primaries with big delegate hauls up for grabs. The race appeared likely to remain competitive until later contests provide more clarity.
Speaking to supporters in Nashua, Mr. Buttigieg, the 38-year-old former mayor of South Bend, Ind., congratulated Mr. Sanders, saying he had admired him when he was in high school and respected him now. He also thanked supporters who saw him as having crossover appeal for voters in the political middle.
"Thanks to you, a campaign that some said shouldn't be here at all, has shown that we are here to stay," Mr. Buttigieg said.
"So many of you decided that a middle-class mayor, a veteran from the industrial Midwest was the right choice to take on this president, not in spite of that experience, but because of it," he said.
While Tuesday was a second strong finish for Mr. Buttigieg, the race gets tougher after this. The former mayor hasn't been polling as well nationally or with minorities, whose support he will need to be successful in the next two contests.
Ms. Klobuchar, who came in fifth in Iowa but outperformed her polling and then had a
strong debate performance in New Hampshire
, now moves on to states on which she has put less emphasis. Her campaign on Tuesday rolled out a seven-figure TV ad buy in Nevada and plans to increase its footprint in that state and in states that will hold contests March 3, known as Super Tuesday.
Ms. Klobuchar pitched herself in remarks Tuesday evening in Concord as the candidate able to assemble a coalition of Democrats, independents and moderate Republicans.
"Hello, America, I'm Amy Klobuchar, and I will beat Donald Trump," she said. "While there are still ballots to count, we have beaten the odds every step of the way."
Mr. Biden and Ms. Warren lagged behind, each below 10% support Tuesday with not all votes counted. Both candidates had played down the significance of this state, with the former vice president leaving early to attend a campaign party in South Carolina.
Ms. Warren took the stage early at her election night event in Manchester and praised Mr. Sanders and Mr. Buttigieg for having "strong nights." She also congratulated Ms. Klobuchar "for showing just how wrong the pundits can be when they count a woman out."
The crowded Democratic field also narrowed as results were coming in, with Colorado Sen.
Michael Bennet
and entrepreneur
Andrew Yang
both ending their bids.
"The math just didn't work out," said Yang campaign manager Zach Graumann.
Though New Hampshire awards just 24 delegates to the Democratic National Convention—candidates need 1,990 to secure the nomination—the state, along with Iowa, can help candidates establish early momentum. Now after races in states that with largely white electorates, the candidates head to Nevada, which has sizable Hispanic and black populations, and South Carolina, where black voters wield considerable power in the state's Democratic primary.
Shortly after South Carolina's Feb. 29 primary will be Super Tuesday, in which the 16 contests will go a long way toward deciding the Democratic nominee.
Exit polls released by television networks indicated that nearly half—48%—of New Hampshire voters surveyed made their decision within the past few days, another indication of a dynamic electorate.
Mr. Biden, who for the past year has attracted the wide majority of support from black voters in polls, is banking on a strong showing in South Carolina to swing the race back his way going into Super Tuesday on March 3. He placed a disappointing fourth in Iowa despite leading in national polling for much of the past year.
Attempting to bypass the loss in New Hampshire, Mr. Biden told supporters in Columbia, S.C., that the country had only heard from two states so far.
"Where I come from, that's the opening bell, not the closing bell," Mr. Biden said. "And the fight to end Donald Trump's presidency is just beginning."
He pointed to the diversity of the electorate in coming states such as Nevada and South Carolina, noting that most of the nation's black and Latino voters had yet to cast a ballot.
Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's impact on the race is also uncertain. He isn't competing in the states voting in February but has spent hundreds of millions of dollars in states that hold primaries in March and later.
Related Coverage
*
Top Takeaways From New Hampshire

*
Andrew Yang Ends Presidential Bid

*
Michael Bennet Drops Out of Presidential Race

John McCormick, Tarini Parti, Sabrina Saddiqui and Ken Thomas contributed to this article.
Write to Chad Day at
Chad.Day@wsj.com
, Eliza Collins at
eliza.collins@wsj.com.
and Joshua Jamerson at
joshua.jamerson@wsj.com

title: U.S. News: Front-Runner Takes Wide Lead In Primary Race
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Democratic presidential primary voters now overwhelmingly back Joe Biden over Bernie Sanders, a dramatic reversal in their standings of just one month ago, the latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll shows.
Among those who have already voted or plan to do so, 61% support the former vice president, while 32% would prefer the Vermont senator as their party's nominee.
The standings are a major change from mid-February, when the survey showed Mr. Sanders backed by 27% of Democratic primary voters and Mr. Biden favored by just 15%.
At the time, Mr. Sanders stood alone as the party's front-runner, while Mr. Biden was among four candidates essentially tied for second place. But Mr. Biden's fortunes changed significantly following his win in South Carolina's Feb. 29 primary and dominance in a string of field-narrowing primaries since then.
The share of Democratic primary voters who say they have definitely settled on a candidate has skyrocketed in the past month, from 37% to 80%, giving Mr. Sanders little room for growth beyond his current base.
Moreover, the coronavirus pandemic, which has altered many aspects of the campaign, is making it harder for Mr. Sanders to break through with his message. It has also eliminated the large rallies that provide much of the fuel for his campaign.
"Bernie Sanders is on a cement trampoline -- not a lot of bounce," said Democratic pollster Peter Hart, who worked on the survey with Jeff Horwitt, also a Democrat, and Republican Bill McInturff.
"The race is sort of locked into place," said Mr. McInturff. "This is very clear, definitive data about the status of this race and the things Bernie Sanders was unable to do to create a coalition."
A televised debate set for Sunday night between the two Democratic candidates will compete for attention with news of the pandemic, which is producing dramatic headlines almost by the hour. Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D., Hawaii), who drew 4% support in the poll, didn't meet Democratic National Committee criteria to qualify for the debate.
The race doesn't look more different among the half of Democrats who have yet to vote than among those who already have cast ballots. Mr. Biden leads by 63% to 30% among primary voters in states that have already held primaries or caucuses and by 60% to 34% in the states that haven't voted.
"There is no indication that this gets easier for Bernie Sanders in the remaining half of the vote," Mr. McInturff said.
The level of enthusiasm among Democratic primary voters for Mr. Biden has also grown in the past month. Some 74% feel enthusiastic about or comfortable with him, up from 56% in February. The share enthusiastic about or comfortable with Mr. Sanders has been stable, at about 66%.
Groups that have swung most dramatically behind Mr. Biden in the last month include African-Americans, among whom he leads by 77% to 18%, as well as liberals and voters who say they are "strongly" aligned with the Democratic Party. Mr. Biden leads by nearly three-to-one among that group.
Looking to the general election, Mr. Biden led President Trump in the new survey by 9 percentage points, 52% to 43%, in a test match-up, while Mr. Sanders led by 4 points, 49% to 45%. Both margins were essentially unchanged from February.
The Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll was based on nationwide telephone interviews of 900 registered voters. It was conducted from March 11-13, 2020, by the polling organizations of Bill McInturff of Public Opinion Strategies and Jeff Horwitt of Hart Research Associates.
The sample was drawn in the following manner: Individuals were randomly selected from national lists of registered voters and were chosen by a systematic procedure to provide a balance of respondents by sex. Respondents reached on their cellphone were randomly selected from national lists of cellphone numbers.
Of the 900 interviews in the weighted data, 495 respondents were reached on a cellphone and screened to ensure that their cellphone was the only phone they had. In addition, 13 respondents were reached on a cellphone but reported also having a landline.
The margin of error for the full sample is plus or minus 3.27 percentage points. Additional interviews were conducted on some questions from a random national sample of Democratic primary voters. For the sample of 438 Democratic primary voters, the margin of error is plus or minus 4.68 percentage points.

title: Sanders, Despite Losses, Sticks to Economic Vision --- Candidate knows he's losing the Democratic nomination but aims to push party to left
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Bernie Sanders concedes he is losing the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination. But the Vermont senator is still fighting a bigger war: his lifelong crusade to push the party's economic agenda to the left.
The candidate wants to dramatically expand government in order to address "the grotesque level of income and wealth inequality in this country," as he put it Wednesday.
Mr. Sanders's uncompromising adherence to his liberal ideals has been both his strength and weakness in this campaign. It energizes his core supporters, who favor his purity over more flexible rivals. But it has also turned off Democrats who dislike his ideas or worry they are unrealistic, and that his stubbornness would keep him from the give-and-take necessary to accomplish change in Washington. As Mr. Sanders himself has acknowledged, many also worry that his far-left position could make it hard to draw enough voters to beat President Trump in a general election. The escalating coronavirus crisis might also make Americans more risk-averse in choosing a leader.
Mr. Sanders argues that voters agree with his platform, even if they are skeptical of his candidacy. "Poll after poll . . . shows that a strong majority of the American people support our progressive agenda," he said, in explaining why he would continue his campaign against front-runner Joe Biden, despite two straight weeks of primary losses and calls for him to drop out and unify the party against Mr. Trump.
He vowed to use Sunday's debate, the first solely between the two candidates, to press his rival for detailed plans for expanding health care, reducing childhood poverty and curbing the political power of billionaires. The candidates face primaries on Tuesday in Arizona, Florida, Illinois and Ohio.
Mr. Sanders's bid to remake Democratic economic thinking remains one of the most intense conflicts in this election cycle, pitting him against affluent party donors and policy makers who share many of his general goals, but prefer a less government-oriented, or more tempered approach.
Surveys indicate a party electorate torn. A February Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed 53% of Democratic voters preferred a candidate pushing Sanders-like "larger scale policies that might cost more" and "bring major change," versus 41% favoring a Biden-like candidate "who proposes smaller scale policies that . . . will bring less change."
But the same poll found Democrats, by 53% to 42%, favored a candidate "with the best chance to defeat Donald Trump" over one "closest to your views" -- and they have increasingly concluded Mr. Biden has the best chance.
When Mr. Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, appeared ascendant last month in the nominating contest, his sweeping platform of national health care, universal free college and a Green New Deal drew blistering criticism from Democratic stalwarts.
Harvard economist Lawrence Summers, a top adviser to both Presidents Clinton and Obama, predicted "major adverse consequences" for workers, markets and business investment should Mr. Sanders prevail. Former Obama White House chief economist Jason Furman, also now at Harvard, said the Sanders program would lead to "too many individuals too constrained from choices" and "a weaker economy." The Progressive Policy Institute, a Washington center-left think tank, branded the platform "fiscal fantasy."
None of that moved Mr. Sanders to soften his policies. Instead, Mr. Sanders and his aides have blasted the criticism and the critics as tainted and out of touch. They blame moderate Democratic economists and think tanks, as much as Republicans, for long-term wage stagnation and other economic worries still haunting millions of Americans.
"We need to think outside the box," said Warren Gunnels, Mr. Sanders's policy adviser. "Over the past 45 years we've seen a massive increase in income and wealth inequality while the working class continues to struggle. It's too late for establishment economics."
Mr. Sanders is more likely to discuss fostering a "moral economy" than strategies to boost gross domestic product, business investment or corporate profits. With his "economic bill of rights," he wants Washington to guarantee all Americans a job, health insurance, college and housing.
Many Democratic economists "would argue those are fine aspirations, but in order to achieve them, you'd have to intervene in markets beyond levels they're comfortable with," said Jared Bernstein, a senior fellow at the left-leaning Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and the chief economist in the Obama administration for then-Vice President Biden.
Mr. Sanders proposes sharply higher taxes, government spending and regulation. He would boost the size of the federal government's share of GDP to a level exceeded only during World War II.
While many Democrats over the past few decades have tried to balance government intervention with market forces, Mr. Sanders has less trust in markets to improve lives. On Thursday, he said his big-government vision of a national health-care plan and price controls on drug companies would put the country on stronger footing to address crises such as the coronavirus pandemic.
At times, he has dismissed cost concerns outright. Asked at a Feb. 18 CNN Las Vegas town hall about the price and feasibility of his plan to phase out fossil fuels, he replied: "You tell me how much is too much if we're talking about saving this planet."
Mr. Sanders wants to smash the conventional wisdom that he says has constrained thinking in Washington since Ronald Reagan -- a consensus that treats higher taxes and new government programs with suspicion -- and reopen discussion of liberal ideas that haven't been seriously considered since the 1970s.
The candidate already claims victory on that front, recounting how proposals from his failed 2016 bid, dismissed at the time as too far left, have since been embraced by Democratic party leaders.
One fight with Hillary Clinton, who won the 2016 Democratic nomination, was over his push to double the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. The Democratic-led House last year passed a bill seeking to make that law, while all his 2020 rival candidates endorsed the goal. Mr. Sanders's 2016 proposal for a Wall Street tax on certain financial transactions was also embraced by much of the 2020 field. Mr. Biden's current positions on many issues, such as expanding Social Security and Medicare, have moved him closer to Mr. Sanders than the longtime Delaware politician has been for much of his career.
"I have been called radical and extreme," Mr. Sanders said in Iowa last year. "Over the last four years . . . a whole lot of other people have become radical and extreme."
Some mainstream center-left economists praise Mr. Sanders's bid to shake up the Washington consensus on restricting spending. "All upper-income democracies in the world have much more generous welfare states than the U.S. and do fine," said Adam Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics, a think tank that has long advised both Republican and Democratic administrations. "We've gone so far off the rails in terms of underinvestment in the public sphere that even a massive shift would only get us part way to where we should be."
The Sanders campaign has been the only major one in this election cycle to avoid even talking to top advisers of previous Democratic presidents. Economists who weren't part of the Clinton or Obama administrations have been close to the Sanders campaign. One is Stephanie Kelton, a professor at Stony Brook University in Stony Brook, N.Y., who served as an aide to Mr. Sanders on the Senate Budget Committee. She is the leading proponent of "modern monetary theory," which argues that governments shouldn't fret over debt and deficits.
Another is Darrick Hamilton of Ohio State University, whose work focuses on what he calls "economic justice." He aims to narrow the wealth gap between black and white households and has been a proponent of the federal job guarantee idea that Mr. Sanders has endorsed.
Mr. Sanders's wealth tax was written with the help of two French economists at the University of California, Berkeley, Emmanuel Saez and Gabriel Zucman.
The Progressive Policy Institute estimates that Mr. Sanders is proposing adding just over $50 trillion in spending over 10 years, nearly doubling the federal government's current outlays. The new funds would mainly be used to expand the social safety net and infrastructure spending.
That is more than eight times the spending proposed by Mr. Biden, according to PPI.
Mr. Sanders would boost taxes by more than $20 trillion over 10 years, according to PPI, by increases in income, payroll and corporate taxes, as well as the new wealth tax.
That is six times the hikes laid out by Mr. Biden.
Most mainstream economists say spending and taxes on that scale would so distort the economy and private-sector activity that it would undermine growth. They warn that significantly higher tax rates could damp incentives for businesses and individuals to invest, while bigger payouts to households could curb incentives to work. They add that attempts by regulators to override market outcomes can impose costly inefficiencies in affected industries.
Mr. Gunnels, the Sanders aide, dismissed concerns about boosting the size of government. "If we were a poor country . . . these would be legitimate questions," he said. "We're not living in a Third World country. It's not too much to ask that everybody in this country has a decent standard of living."
Sanders allies said his platform has successful parallels: Franklin D. Roosevelt's 1930s New Deal, which created Social Security and a raft of new government programs and regulations; and Lyndon B. Johnson's 1960s Great Society, which created Medicare and new antipoverty initiatives.
Harvard's Mr. Summers said the scale of Mr. Sanders's proposals would far exceed anything FDR or LBJ enacted, or even what South Dakota Democratic Sen. George McGovern proposed during his 1972 landslide loss to Richard Nixon, a defeat that helped usher in the party's retreat from liberalism.
If Mr. Sanders enacted his full program, government as a share of GDP would jump from the 2017 level of about 38%, one of the lowest levels in the developed world, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, to more than 50%. That is well above any peacetime level in U.S. history, but in line with European countries such as France and Denmark.
He also envisions a raft of new government regulations, from national rent control to new rules for CEO pay to an outright ban on fracking.
While some Democratic economists prefer to address climate change with market incentives, such as a carbon tax, Mr. Sanders would rely more on direct government orders. To protect energy workers who might lose their jobs, he promises five years of government-guaranteed salary, plus housing assistance, pension support and retirement subsidies for those who decide not to continue working.
That "would be an utter nightmare to enforce," said Dean Baker, an economist at the liberal Center for Economic and Policy Research, saying it would be difficult to flesh out the criteria for who exactly would qualify.
Mr. Sanders would aim to shrink the role of the financial sector in the economy by, among other things, breaking up the largest banks, and reimposing Depression-era limits on banking activity.
He would make it harder for employers to fire workers, unionized or not, and would require big companies to give workers shares of company stock and the right to choose nearly half the seats on corporate boards. His goal is to recalibrate the balance of power between corporations and unions, who have seen their clout erode steadily over the past 40 years.
"In Bernie Sanders's world, the market doesn't come from a state of nature, it comes out of an allocation of power," said Robert Reich, a Berkeley public policy professor, who served as President Clinton's labor secretary and has periodically defended Mr. Sanders against attacks from other academics. "The standard economic view is that the market is filled with potential win-win opportunities, but when you're talking about power, it's more complicated. Some people gain it and others lose it."
---
Eliza Collins contributed to this article.

title: Industries Fret Over Potential Bernie Sanders Presidency --- Targets of proposals say he would be limited in implementing them
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
The rapid ascent of Sen. Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primaries -- despite a weak showing in Saturday's South Carolina vote -- confronts American business with the once unthinkable: The most powerful policy maker in the world could soon be a strident, lifelong critic of capitalism and big business.
Current and former business leaders and analysts have greeted the prospect with a mix of concern, skepticism and disbelief. Most doubt the Vermont independent, who calls himself a democratic socialist and caucuses with Democrats, could win against President Trump in November, and if he does, could not or would not implement his boldest ideas.
If they are wrong, some see an existential threat. For most businesses, contingency planning boils down to one word: Congress. Health companies assume a Republican-controlled Senate would block Medicare for All, which would ban private insurance.
If, along with a Sanders win, the Democrats take both the House and Senate, "There would be a close to apoplectic reaction" in the health-care sector, said Chet Burrell, former chief executive of CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield, which offers coverage in Maryland and the Washington, D.C., area. "There would be an intense effort to intercede. . .and shape what would happen."
In energy, Mr. Sanders seeks to shut down the extraction of oil and gas, in particular by banning hydraulic fracturing, or "fracking," of shale deposits, to deal with climate change.
"The shale revolution has created many, many jobs in the last decade," said J. Nelson Wood, chief executive of Wood Energy Inc., a small oil and gas producer in Illinois, that employs 25 people and operates 200 wells. "That effectively ends if his policies are implemented."
Mr. Sanders and his supporters argue policies under past presidents of both parties have disproportionately benefited the wealthy and corporations while ordinary workers' wages stagnated. They say his policies would address essential needs such as health insurance and climate change. They say jobs lost would be more than offset by jobs gained elsewhere.
They also play down the socialist label. Mr. Sanders has said he doesn't want the government to take over the means of production, the textbook definition of socialism. "What democratic socialism is about is saying, 'Let's use the federal government to protect the interests of working families,' " he said on "60 Minutes."
"If you're a modern day robber baron, then the policies of a Bernie Sanders administration will not be to your liking," said Josh Orton, Mr. Sanders's policy director, in an interview. "If you are a small or medium-size businessthat desperately needs infrastructure, [such as] high-speed internet access to prosper in rural areas, or a manufacturing company or worker sick of free-trade agreements that have offshored production, then you will like the agenda of a Bernie Sanders administration."
Mr. Sanders places himself in the tradition of previous Democratic presidents like Franklin Delano Roosevelt -- whose policies, Mr. Sanders has noted, were often labeled socialism. Mr. Roosevelt eschewed the socialist label even as he created a social safety net and enacted sweeping curbs on business.While running for re-election in 1936, he claimed, "The old enemies of peace: business and financial monopoly, speculation, reckless banking, class antagonism, sectionalism, war profiteering. . .are unanimous in their hate for me -- and I welcome their hatred."
Today, critics on the right predict Mr. Sanders's policies would be catastrophic for the economy. Casey Mulligan, an economist at the University of Chicago who served in Mr. Trump's White House, predicted Mr. Sanders's policies would significantly shrink gross domestic product by discouraging work and investment with higher taxes and by replacing private ownership in some industries with less efficient public ownership.
Left-of-center economists dismiss those estimates as unfounded. Gabriel Zucman, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley who has advised Mr. Sanders and Sen. Elizabeth Warren, another presidential candidate, on tax policy, noted in Scandinavia, which has an economic system closest to what Mr. Sanders seeks, average income per adult and average wealth per adult are about the same as in the U.S. He said broadening access to education and health care historically has helped growth, and he said Medicare for All would significantly boost household purchasing power by eliminating insurance premiums.
Only once has Mr. Sanders ever actually held the reins of government, as mayor of Burlington, Vt., from 1981 to 1989. "Bernie understood that you need business making a profit in order to do the social, environmental and cultural good that he espouses," said Tom Torti, current president of the Lake Champlain Regional Chamber of Commerce, who has known Mr. Sanders since then and is neutral in the current race.
At the time, a private businessman wanted to redevelop the waterfront. Mr. Sanders intervened to favor a different plan that resulted in below-market rate boat slips for local residents, public access and a community sailing center, Mr. Torti said. It is now "a profitable development," he said. "People make money. It's capitalism working with a social conscience."
Nowadays, Mr. Sanders seldom utters the word capitalism without modifiers like "unfettered," "out of control" and "casino." By contrast, Ms. Warren, who advocates many of the same policies, such as Medicare for All, calls herself a "capitalist to my bones."
Yet business and investors have been less exercised about Mr. Sanders's rise to front-runner than when Ms. Warren briefly reached the same position last fall.
Sarah Bianchi, a policy analyst at broker Evercore ISI, said one reason is that they thought Ms. Warren could beat Mr. Trump, but that Mr. Sanders couldn't. Prediction markets show that as the probability of Mr. Sanders winning the nomination rose clearly above 50% this year, so did the probability of Mr. Trump being re-elected.
Another reason, Ms. Bianchi said, is that Ms. Warren's affinity for the minutiae of policy suggests she would be more determined and effective at implementing her ideas.
By contrast, Mr. Sanders has been criticized for his lack of detail, in particular how he will pay for his programs. Cornerstone Macro, an investment research firm, estimates Mr. Sanders's promises would cost $67 trillion over the coming decade, but his tax increases would raise less than half that.
Mr. Sanders told "60 Minutes" he didn't have a price tag for all of his proposals but said "we have options out there" to finance Medicare for All. These include income-based premiums on individuals and employers that, his campaign said, would be lower than what most now pay in premiums.
Mr. Sanders has proposed sharply cutting drug costs, which he says are inflated by pharmaceutical companies, to what other wealthy countries pay. He would allow Medicare to negotiate drug prices and allow importation of drugs from other countries, and set prices according to an index based on international rates.
Ian Spatz, a health-care consultant, said the moves would hurt the development of new medicines. "When push comes to shove, do members of Congress want to kill the goose that lays the golden pharmaceutical eggs," he said.
Even without passing Medicare for All, Mr. Sanders could crimp health insurers' growth or margins through regulatory actions -- for instance, tweaking the rules on how they manage the private version of Medicare plans, a key business for the industry.
In energy, Mr. Sanders would withhold federal permits for any fossil-fuel infrastructure such as pipelines. He would also require electricity and transportation to be entirely based on renewable energy by 2030. Yet the necessary technology, such as for electric cars that are affordable for most consumers and profitable for manufacturers, doesn't yet exist.
"Nothing he does and says will make cars and trucks move without gasoline," said Chris Wright, chief executive of Liberty Oilfield Services, which operates fracking equipment. "All he can do is harm domestic production, drive up prices, and turn us from an exporter to importer."
Mr. Sanders's campaign proposes "massive investments in research and development" to "drastically reduce" the cost of energy storage and electric vehicles.
Kevin Book, research director at ClearView Energy Partners, an energy research firm, said a ban on private fracking wouldn't pass Congress so long as the Senate requires 60 votes for major legislation, and Trump-appointed judges would likely curb overly expansive regulatory action.
Mr. Book said that, much as Mr. Trump declared a national emergency on the southern border to justify redirecting federal funds to build a wall, Mr. Sanders could use his proposed designation of climate change as a national emergency to ban fossil fuel exports and shut down offshore drilling.
Mr. Orton of the Sanders campaign said that because scientists say the world has a tight window to take action before climate change does irreparable damage, "We are not going to let the fossil-fuel industry complain that we're not going to compromise. They were uncompromising in their greed for the 40 years that they spent causing this crisis."
Some of the fiercest opposition to Mr. Sanders comes from Wall Street. In an op-ed in Time Magazine, JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive James Dimon said socialism would be "a disaster for our country." Former Goldman Sachs Group Inc. chief executive Lloyd Blankfein, a lifelong Democrat, told the Financial Times "I might find it harder to vote for Bernie than for Trump."
Mr. Sanders, who advocates the Depression-era separation of banks and securities dealers and a tax on financial transactions, has reveled in their criticism. He has shot back at Mr. Blankfein on Twitter with barbs about his pay. One of his ads called Mr. Dimon "the biggest corporate socialist" in the country, citing the financial-crisis era bank bailouts and fines. JPMorgan has said it didn't need a bailout in 2008 and accepted one only at the urging of the Treasury, and quickly repaid it.
Yet some on Wall Street don't consider Mr. Sanders much more risky than other Democratic candidates, all of whom, including Mr. Bloomberg, have promised to tax or regulate finance more. "No one is freaking out," said one banker. "It will be tougher under a Democratic president, but it can be tougher in a 100 different ways." Most presidents, he said, have only enough political capital to accomplish one or two big things in their first term, and Mr. Sanders is likely to spend his on health care rather than banking, which has attracted little attention in the campaign.
Compared to energy and health care, Mr. Sanders's ideas for remaking corporate governance have drawn less attention but are potentially more sweeping. He proposes that employees own at least 20% of large or public companies' shares and elect 45% of their directors. Companies that lay off employees because of foreign outsourcing or automation would have to issue them shares as compensation. Companies with larger gaps between executive and worker pay would pay higher tax rates. A new federal charter, mandatory for large and public companies, would require boards to consider the interests not just of shareholders, but of workers, customers and communities. Companies could be required to include women and minorities on boards.
Steven Fazzari, an economist at Washington University in St. Louis, said increased stock ownership by middle- and lower-income Americans could help offset rising income and wealth inequality, while rules "that would push big business to improve diversity could be helpful in addressing multiple dimensions of inequality over time."
Corporate governance experts said the plans would create internal governance problems. Employees wouldn't be independent directors, so conflict-of-interest rules would prevent them from serving on committees overseeing audits, board nominations and executive compensation, "which is where the critical work of the company gets done," said Amy Borrus, deputy director of the Council of Institutional Investors.
Issuing 20% of shares to employees would, by diluting existing shareholders' returns, make a company's stock less attractive, encouraging it to issue more debt, said Nicholas Bloom, an economist at Stanford University. That would make it more leveraged and vulnerable to bankruptcy, he said.
And shareholders would likely sue to contest the expropriation of ownership and control from existing shareholders to employees, said B. Espen Eckbo, a finance professor who founded Dartmouth College's corporate-governance research center.
---
David Benoit, Christopher M. Matthews, Anna Wilde Mathews and Theo Francis contributed to this article.

title: Democrats Give Cold Shoulder to Big Wall Street Donor; M&A lawyer H. Rodgin Cohen is shunned over financial-crisis and Weinstein roles; public health experts express alarm at Trump officials' rhetoric on virus
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
DEMOCRATS' WARINESS OF WALL STREET MONEY has complicated the political giving of one of the Street's most prominent M&A lawyers.
H. Rodgin Cohen, chairman of law firm Sullivan & Cromwell, is a prolific Democratic donor, giving to state parties and House, Senate and presidential campaigns. He has donated between $2,500 and $5,600 to six Democratic Senate challengers and four incumbents running for re-election this cycle—Michigan's Gary Peters, Alabama's Doug Jones, Minnesota's Tina Smith and Virginia's Mark Warner. He has donated to multiple Democratic presidential campaigns, including Joe Biden's and Pete Buttigieg's.
But Buttigieg returned
Cohen's donations
following a flurry of press about Cohen's Wall Street dealings, which included advising firms at the center of the 2008 financial crisis such as Lehman Brothers and American International Group Inc. (Some candidates, such as Sens. Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, have been explicit about not accepting any financial industry donations.)
The campaigns were contacted by the Journal and informed of Cohen's Wall Street history, as well as his 2015 review of Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein's personnel file for his company's board, in which Cohen found "no unresolved claims that could result in liability." After being asked for comment, the Peters and Jones campaigns said they were each donating $5,000 to nonprofits focused on sexual assault, equivalent to the amount of Cohen's donations.
Weinstein Co.'s board hired Cohen to look at the file after Weinstein's expenses and women's allegations of misconduct came to their attention. Cohen's review of Weinstein preceded the board's decision to renew Weinstein's contract later that year. Weinstein was convicted on sex-crimes charges this week in New York. Cohen declined to comment. Warner's campaign declined to comment. The Smith and Biden campaigns didn't respond to requests for comment.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
Do you expect more Democratic candidates will refuse money from Wall Street-connected donors? Why or why not? Join the conversation below.
TRUST IN AMERICAN INSTITUTIONS faces yet another test with the coronavirus epidemic. Some public health experts are alarmed at the rhetoric of elected and Trump administration officials relating to the outbreak. Some have presented a rosy outlook for the virus, with White House adviser Larry Kudlow on Tuesday claiming that the virus is "contained," contradicting Centers for Disease Control officials. "The impulse to mitigate economic harm is not a bad one," said Dr. Margaret Bourdeaux, research director for Harvard Belfer Center's Security and Global Health Project. "But you can't PR your way out of a crisis."
Republican Sen. Tom Cotton and Homeland Security's Ken Cuccinelli have suggested that the virus could have been developed as a biological weapon in a laboratory in Wuhan, China, the epidemic's epicenter.
A group of scientists pushed back strongly
on that theory in the Lancet, a medical journal. "We stand together to strongly condemn conspiracy theories suggesting that COVID-19 does not have a natural origin," they wrote of the virus. Cotton has said
he "cannot rule out any explanation yet
," and Democratic and Republican leaders have traded insults about each other's handling of the crisis.
MASSACHUSETTS sees dogfight ahead of its Super Tuesday primary. Warren's advisers believe they can win her home state, though some have said they expect to see a competitive race.
A recent poll
shows Warren and Sanders almost tied in the state, with Buttigieg, Biden and Michael Bloomberg not far behind. Warren received a boost from the Boston Globe on Wednesday, which endorsed her after saying in December 2018 that she shouldn't run.
Sanders makes an overt play for the state with rallies there Friday and Saturday. Buttigieg put staffers on the ground in Massachusetts last week, and Bloomberg opened a Boston suburban field office in Medford, his hometown, with actor Michael Douglas. Sen. Amy Klobuchar has made digital ad investments and aims to pick off delegates in specific congressional districts. Biden still has hopes of winning the state or at least amassing delegates, and he has won the support of numerous party and union leaders in the state.
ANTI-PIPELINE ACTIVISTS aim to push fight against Atlantic Coast Pipeline into public consciousness, like previous battles against Keystone and Dakota Access pipelines. The Supreme Court heard oral arguments Monday on whether to reinstate a construction permit for the pipeline, which would be built through two national forests and the Appalachian Trail. Twelve activists were arrested outside the court as a majority of the
justices signaled they were likely to allow
the permission process to go forward.
AMERICAN CATHOLICS disapprove of Trump at similar rates as the general population, and most would favor a Democratic challenger over the president in the election, according to
a new poll
from RealClear Opinion Research and EWTN News, a Catholic broadcast network. Among devout Catholics, who accept all or most of the Church's teachings, Trump's approval ratings are the highest: 63%, with 59% planning to vote for him. The devout Catholics surveyed were 41% Hispanic, which suggests higher support for Trump than the Hispanic population at large, which gave Trump around 28% of their votes in 2016, according to exit polls.
MINOR MEMOS: Department of Homeland Security makes grammar error in rule about legal immigrants' English proficiency.… Sen. Chuck Schumer confirms
he spent $8,600 of campaign funds
on New York restaurant Junior's cheesecake in past decade.…Singer Garth Brooks' fans mistake his Detroit Lions Barry Sanders jersey for signal of support for Bernie Sanders.
Write to Gabriel T. Rubin at
gabriel.rubin@wsj.com

title: Democrats Face a Stark Choice on Super Tuesday From Coast to Coast; Presidential primary voters struggled to choose between calls for pragmatism and sweeping policy changes
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





Martha Mendoza, right, helped a voter with the new voting system at Roosevelt Middle School in Los Angeles on Tuesday. PHOTO: Allison Zaucha for The Wall Street Journal
RALEIGH, N.C.—Democratic voters from here to California said they struggled to choose between pragmatism and policy on Tuesday, mirroring a national debate over whether sweeping political and economic changes or moderation were the keys to defeating President Trump.
Freelance marketing consultant Julie Cook, who had considered Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders because of his health-care plans, woke up Tuesday planning to vote for former Vice President Joe Biden, but hours later bubbled in former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg.
Ms. Cook said she liked that Mr. Bloomberg plans to spend whatever it takes to win, noting she has struggled to explain Mr. Trump's verbose behavior to her 4- and 6-year-old daughters.
Mr. Trump "is ridiculous," said Ms. Cook, 37 years old. "It's gotten to the point that I can't stand to look at him on TV anymore."
In Houston, onetime Hillary Clinton-backer Julia Kibbel voted for Mr. Sanders because of her work with the uninsured as a nurse practitioner in the county health department.
"He seems to be consistent, and he's more" focused on social services, said Ms. Kibbel, 40.
Mr. Biden enjoyed a boost in the 72 hours before Super Tuesday, scoring a blowout win in South Carolina's primary Saturday and then securing endorsements from three opponents who left the race—former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar and former Texas Rep. Beto O'Rourke.
Many voters said the recent near-daily shifts in the Democratic field have made their choices fluid.
In Modesto, Calif., semi-retired ironworker Scott Szuggar, 54, said he was glad he held on to his mail-in ballot for a week. "I kind of had a feeling that people were going to drop out," he said, as he left his ballot at a downtown voting center.
Mr. Szuggar said he had been leaning toward Mr. Bloomberg but cast his vote for Mr. Biden because he seemed to have momentum. "He is starting to pick up a little steam here," he said. 





Angela Delgado voted at Compton High School in Los Angeles on Saturday. PHOTO: Allison Zaucha for The Wall Street Journal
Andrew Morrison, 50, a resident of Los Alamitos, Calif., who works in plastics manufacturing, voted for Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, though he said she wasn't likely to get the nomination. "If she can pick up some California delegates, it gives her more power to become a player later," he said.
At the Community College of Denver, Rebecca Turner, 26, an eco-psychology major, voted early for Mr. Sanders, but worries that he may not fare well in the general election.
"In a perfect world, Bernie Sanders would be my president," she said. If he doesn't get the nomination, she said she would vote for Mr. Biden. "Bernie is the, 'Oh I wish,' and Biden is the 'That'll probably do.' "
Voting centers on the Westside of Los Angeles were busy Tuesday morning, with some voters popping their heads in to judge the lines before committing to casting ballots before work.
Anya McGrath said she voted for Mr. Sanders inside an elementary school auditorium in the city's Mar Vista neighborhood. "He is just more in touch with people like me, middle America," said Ms. McGrath, 36, a preschool teacher. "He speaks for underserved people. I'm kind of all about getting money out of the hands of billionaires and getting it back to the people."
Ms. McGrath said Ms. Warren was "a close second," adding, "I would take her," as she sat on a bench outside Beethoven Street Elementary School. "I would take anyone but Trump." 





Voter Alexandra Keen, 29, held her daughter as she cast her ballot at Lowe's Grove Baptist Church in Durham, N.C., on Tuesday. PHOTO: Victor J. Blue for The Wall Street Journal
Back in Raleigh, roofer Larry Bostic, 34, said he chose Mr. Biden after watching last week's feisty debate in Charleston, S.C. "That thing was fierce," he said. "Biden was the only one up there maintaining professionalism. Everyone else was throwing jabs. We don't need that right now."
Mr. Bostic, who is African-American, said Mr. Sanders's criminal-justice policies would help some of his friends who have made bad choices. But he said he couldn't get comfortable with his style.
"Imagine if you went to work one day and somebody asked you what you were doing and you just went, 'Rah rah!' " he said, holding up his arms and shaking his wrists. "You got to leave your feelings at the door a little bit."
Lighting a cigarette, Mr. Bostic looked at the ground and said he had to admit that he had considered not voting. He said he had felt like his vote for Mrs. Clinton in 2016 didn't count when she won the popular vote but Mr. Trump won the White House.
"It feels hopeless to a lot of Americans," he said. "But the idea of not doing anything and having an opinion? If you're not going to vote, don't complain."
Elizabeth Findell in Houston; Alejandro Lazo in Modesto, Calif.; Ian Lovett in Seal Beach, Calif.; Deborah Acosta in Denver; and Alicia Caldwell in Los Angeles contributed to this article. 





A voter filled out a ballot at City Hall in Montpelier, Vt. on Tuesday. PHOTO: Cheryl Senter for The Wall Street Journal
Write to Valerie Bauerlein at
valerie.bauerlein@wsj.com
